content: The "Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act" establishes a Commission with specific duties, powers, and personnel matters. It also includes provisions for a final report, Congressional hearings, authorization of appropriations, and termination of the Commission. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission to address soaring medical malpractice premiums by proposing a comprehensive strategy. The Commission will consist of 12 members appointed by the President to represent various interests including physicians, malpractice liability insurers, lawyers, and consumer protection. Qualifications for members include expertise in medicine, insurance, law, consumer affairs, or other relevant fields, and they should not be officers or employees of the United States. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President to represent various interests. Members should represent a broad cross-section of regional and political perspectives in the United States and provide fresh insights into analyzing the medical malpractice insurance crisis. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Emergency Malpractice Liability Insurance Commission (EMLIC) Act establishes a Commission with 12 members appointed by the President to represent various interests. Members should provide fresh insights into analyzing the medical malpractice insurance crisis. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, elect a chairperson and vice chairperson from among its members, with a majority constituting a quorum for voting, where each member is entitled to 1 vote. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will investigate the relationship between rising malpractice insurance premiums, jury awards, and the impact on healthcare accessibility. Recommendations will be based on statistical trends and testimony to address the crisis in medical malpractice liability insurance. The Commission will also examine the nature of the medical malpractice insurance market and its differences from other insurance lines, as well as the impact of the McCarran-Ferguson Act. The Commission will investigate the impact of the McCarran-Ferguson Act on the medical malpractice insurance market, federal role and recommendations, State-level legislation efficacy, insurer's investments and premium rate setting, role of jury awards, relationship between premium rates and medical practice costs, and the dispersion of malpractice claims across the medical community. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 16 months of the Act's enactment. The report will include findings, a strategy to address rising medical malpractice insurance rates, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. Members can also submit additional views. Congressional hearings will follow within 6 months of the final report. Upon submission of the final report, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions will conduct hearings on the report. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. They must hold at least 7 public hearings, including some in Washington, D.C. and different regions of the United States. Additionally, the Commission can request information from federal departments and agencies as needed. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as government employees or not. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairperson can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Commission to implement the Act. The Comptroller General will audit the Commission's finances within 6 months of its termination. The Commission will dissolve 30 days after submitting the final report.
